Let's test your knowledge of the Bayes factor!

We will use a common setting across all questions: 
<br>
Compare the null hypothesis $\mathcal{H}_0: \mu_1=\mu_2$ to the alternative hypothesis $\mathcal{H}_1: \mu_1\not=\mu_2$.

```{r questions_database}
questions <- quiz(
  caption = "", 
  
  
  question(
    paste0("Suppose that, a prior, "),
    answer("base"),
    answer("tools"),
    answer("utils", correct = TRUE),
    answer("codetools"), 
    incorrect = "Upsy daisy!", 
    correct   = "Yes!", 
    allow_retry = TRUE, 
    try_again = "Please try again!", 
    post_message = "This is what I will say to wrap this question up.", 
    random_answer_order	= TRUE
  ), 
  
  question(
    "Which of the R packages listed below are used to create plots?",
    answer("lattice", correct = TRUE),
    answer("tools"),
    answer("stats"),
    answer("grid", correct = TRUE)
  )
)

n.questions    <- 1:length(questions[[2]]) # sample(1:length(questions[[2]]), length(questions[[2]]), replace = FALSE)
questions[[2]] <- questions[[2]][n.questions]
questions
```

output$distPlot <- renderPlot({
  x <- faithful[, 2]  # Old Faithful Geyser data
  bins <- seq(min(x), max(x), length.out = input$bins + 1)
  hist(x, breaks = bins, col = 'darkgray', border = 'white')
})
